intro: Chaerophyllum borodinii, commonly known as the Borodin's cow parsley, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in meadows and along riverbanks. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
